body: The distributed test failure is unrelated to this PR. `RepeatedRebalanceDUnitTest.testSecondRebalanceIsNotNecessaryWithAddedAndRestartedMembers` is known to fail intermittently:  https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-7603
The stress test failures are due to another test method in this class. That test method is being addressed in a separate PR: https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/6748
The distributed test failure is from a test known to fail intermittently: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-7183
The distributed test failure is unrelated to this PR. It is due to a test known to fail intermittently: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-7739
Closing as duplicate of: https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/6744

Thanks @mkevo for your reviews. I had the `gradlew build` already executed before submitting the PR. However, thanks for the other command `gradlew spotlessApply`. All looking good with both. Also have changed the title of the PR to follow the standard.

![Screen Shot 2021-08-11 at 8 52 08 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10272355/129031805-ec99de34-24b9-4dca-8da2-54ce238fa871.png)

The build passed because everything is okay in productive code and in unit tests. But your fault is in integration tests which are not ran with gradlew build. So you can try to do gradlew spotlessApply and then with git status check modified files and add them in a new commit.
Absolutely, I noticed how it cleaned the whitespaces :) and I agree, it has to build for sure no matter what changes are applied to the file. Thanks once again.

Hi @upthewaterspout , and thanks for the question. Sorry, missed this in my inbox. I commented out, not removed, these sections, so that the guidance appears in the PR when contributors write the content for the PR description, but that the content doesn't appear when displaying after the PR has published. The content is still available when re-editing the PR.

> I agree @DonalEvans and thanks for your review comments. I am on it :).

The changes in the most recent commit don't really address the issue I'm afraid. The test names should be made more descriptive to make it clear what behaviour is under test. Simply removing the "003", "004" etc. doesn't achieve this. A good guide for how to write descriptive test names and why doing so is helpful can be found here: https://osherove.com/blog/2005/4/3/naming-standards-for-unit-tests.html
Thanks for working on this change! Please give me a day or so to finish reviewing.

This pull request **introduces 2 alerts** when merging 126477f2b1ad8d6e2287dee9c84a95c6d3b713fb into a10a56f573e9a4aabf3c5b6e3862539d6dd93b92 - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/apache/geode/rev/pr-fd7ee1b94b33e7ace6dabbb0cad08a77309f3a87)

@DonalEvans, I have committed the changes that triggered the build actions, but this one CI "concourse-ci/distributed-test-openjdk8" is failing. Do you have any idea how to restart that or what could be wrong?

> @DonalEvans, I have committed the changes that triggered the build actions, but this one CI "concourse-ci/distributed-test-openjdk8" is failing. Do you have any idea how to restart that or what could be wrong?

If you click on the "details" link next to the failed job, it will open [the Concourse page](https://concourse.apachegeode-ci.info/builds/65859) for the job, which has a section called "execute_tests-openjdk8" which will be red for a failed run. Expanding this section allows you to find the test that failed (the section can be large, so searching for "failed" saves having to scroll past lots of unimportant gradle output), which in this case is [ShutdownAllDUnitTest.testShutdownAllWithMembersWaiting()](https://concourse.apachegeode-ci.info/builds/65859#L60e863bb:583).

Searching the GEODE JIRA for this test name shows that [we have an existing ticket](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-9038) for this failure. Unfortunately there are a lot of known flaky tests in Geode, particularly in the distributed-test jobs, so it's not uncommon to hit them in pre-checkin.

The good news, though, is that it is not mandatory for all pre-checkin jobs to be passing in order to merge a PR, only the ones marked "required" on GitHub, so a PR with an unrelated flaky failure in one of the non-required jobs can still be merged. However, if you want to re-trigger the job for the sake of getting a fully green pre-checkin, you can always push an empty commit which will cause the job to run again.

> This is a good change. I'll approve as soon as you've added some comments in `SystemPropertyHelper` describing the new property.

D
Force pushing to resolve merge conflicts due to GEODE‑9186.

Alright, so even after re-running the task "concourse-ci/distributed-test-openjdk8" via an empty commit, it's still failing, so not sure if we are ok with this to still get the PR approved.

> Alright, so even after re-running the task "concourse-ci/distributed-test-openjdk8" via an empty commit, it's still failing, so not sure if we are ok with this to still get the PR approved.

It's (sadly) pretty normal for there to be a flaky failure in the pre-checkin, so as long as it's been confirmed that the cause of the job failing is a known issue (the most recent one seems to be [GEODE-8411](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-8411)), it's fine to merge the PR. It's often helpful for reviewers if you can identify the cause of the flaky failure and leave a comment saying what it is, so they know it's nothing to worry about.

That being said, I would appreciate it if you could address [this comment](https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/6757#issuecomment-900595283) to update the test names to be more descriptive before this gets merged.

This is magic, the test "concourse-ci/acceptance-test-openjdk11" passed this time without any changes :)

Stores deltas for RedisData in a static ThreadLocal in the RedisData class, which avoids carrying around an object reference for all instances of RedisData. This saves 4-8 bytes of memory per RedisData instance.

Instead of using different vm for different version client, a parameterized test would be more appropriate since we should keep adding newer versions to the test. Try add this test to `AuthExpirationDUnitTest` as that is already a parameterized test. This could be just a another test method added there. This tests a single server with different version of client. I would suggest also adding a test to the `AuthExpirationMultiServerDUnitTest`,  and test those `onRegion`, `onServer` and `onServers` calls and verify behavior is as expected.

> Use of simple security manager does not seem like a good idea. We should not depend on examples code as klund said.
> 
> Other than that things look good.

ExpirableSecurityManager is a test security manager.

> First off - I love the change to SanctionedSerializablesService. A lot cleaner!
> 
> In the future, it would better not to bundle these unrelated changes together. The RestRegionAPIIntegrationTest and QueryCommandDUnitTestBase stuff really doesn't have anything to do with serialization service changes and shouldn't be in here.
> 
> Edit: approved the changed - what I thought was a problem is in test code, not product.

@upthewaterspout QueryCommandDUnitTestBase is actually one of the few (maybe only) DUnit tests that directly exercises the serialization filter in Geode with an expected failure. I only touched it because its subclasses started failing when I added sanctioned serializables support to geode-dunit.

RestRegionAPIIntegrationTest does not have anything to do with the serialization filter, however it broke because of changes I made to geode-web-api's build.gradle file. After making changes to it for debugging and understanding what it was doing, I decided to include it since it was part of the "work" I had to do rather than jump through hoops to move it to a different branch.

So, QueryCommandDUnitTestBase is actually part of the changes for serialization filtering. The second one was not, but it was included because it was part of a problem area (our REST code) that blocked the work for two days (see GEODE-9504 geode-web-api needs unit tests).
@kirklund - Makes sense. Thanks for taking on refactoring this stuff!

@onichols-pivotal No, I think that must be an option that's enabled in IntelliJ. I committed from IntelliJ's git plugin. I'll fix it up.
Thanks for the review. Closing this PR and incorporate the changes in a coming PR.

@kirklund Regarding unit tests for the classes you mentioned; a decision was made by the folks who're working on the Geode Redis module to rely predominantly on integration tests to validate the behaviour of the Geode Redis API. Unit tests are used to test components that are not accessible via the API (such as object sizing for rebalance, the internal data structures that back the various RedisData classes etc.) but it was not considered worthwhile to also unit test methods that are covered in their entirety via integration tests.

Adding unit tests to the classes you list would represent a fundamental change in testing approach for the group working on the Geode Redis module, and as such, it feels like something that would be better brought to the dev list if it's a change that you feel really needs to be made, since it was originally a deliberate choice rather than an oversight.
Reopening with fix and clean testing.

HI Dave,
          I had reported this problem to Juan who raised  the jira and the intention of this jira was to remove the upper bound of this range of timeout which is set to 12437ms and make it User configuratble. I mean user should be able to configure it using member-timeout or  if you want to provide any other config. The issue is in big network , some components might take more time(more than 12437ms) to reconnect to cluster during membership change. Since this  is set to a small value 12437ms so those members get thrown out of cluster. I looked into the code change and doc change, and I see the upper limit is still there. This won't solve the problem for which this jira was raised.
       Can you please take a relook into this issue.
